 Yes Steve, that's exactly what it means. That's the entire point of the clause. The "Full faith and credit" clause is intended to provide continuity between the states for non-federal rulings and legal proceedings. Rather than have a hodge-podge of legal conditions which would hinge on which states were dealing with each other, the legal dealing of any state are automatically recognized by all states. For example, if you get married in Vegas, you're married in your home state too, even if you wouldn't have been given a marriage license there. You may be too young, not have had a blood test, not have gone through the waiting period. Doesn't matter. Even if you don't meet any of the criteria to get a license in your state, the fact that you got married in Vegas means you're married, in every sense of the word, and in every state in the country.
